markdownRemark.html:
Program errors are intended to express unexpected events during the carrying out of a set of instructions. To a computer, at the lowest level, an instruction could be take these binary values (inputs), perform a logical operation, and generate a new binary value (output). In this idealised model there is not really much unexpected that could happen — other than the power socket being yanked out. Typically this level of instruction is not under consideration for day to day programming. It is too low level. Advances in the field of hardware and software have enable programmers to combine over hundreds of thousands of these lower level instructions using text with semantic value to humans. This is enabled by layering concepts over patterns we see in these lower level instruction. This is called abstraction and is a very powerful idea in Computer Science. Travelling all the way up the onion we arrive at text we read and program. Let’s call this the text representation of our program. It is one description of the program, and it happens to the be one that programmers interact with the most.

Where does this leave errors? Often, somewhere wedged between these layers. The reality is errors happen at different levels. It could be that errors occur because a carelessly scripted section of an application failed to consider an edge case. It could be that a layer separating our representation of the program
